Federal RMP Executive Summary

Air Products and Chemicals, Inc.
LaPorte, Texas Facility

1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

At this facility, we manufacture gaseous hydrogen.  Hydrogen in the amount handled by this facility, is considered hazardous by EPA.  Liquid Chlorine is used for cooling water treatment, specifically as a biocide.  Chlorine in the amount handled by this facility, is considered hazardous by EPA.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Air Products manages the safety of the regulated processes by means of operating procedures, equipment testing and inspections, safety devices, (e.g. alarms, shutdowns, instrumentation, relief devices) inherent in the design of this facility and other controls and systems designed to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices and training of our personnel supplement the inherent safe design of the plant.

Our emergency response program is based upon OSHA?s HAZWOPER regulation.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for the request of local fire support through Channel Industries Mutual Aid so that appropriate measures can be taken by local emergency responders to control releases.

This document has been prepared in accordance with the EPA?s Risk Management Plan regulation (40 CFR, Part 68).  The substances and processes considered during the preparation of this RMP and the scenarios described were selected based on criteria established in the regulation.

2.  The stationary sources and regulated substances handled:

One of the principal purposes of this facility is to manufacture gaseous hydrogen.  Gaseous hydrogen is used by our customers in their manufacturing processes.  Gaseous Hydrogen is produced in the partial oxidation process unit and transmitted to the customers via pipelines.  In addition, hydrogen is filled into DOT regulated tube trailers for the over road deliveries to customers.

The pipelines are connected to a 20,000-gallon liquid hydrogen backup tank that supplies the pipelines when the partial oxidation process unit is shut down.

Liquid Chlorine is used for cooling water treatment, specifically as a biocide.  The chlorine is stored in 1-ton containers, two of which are located on site.

Process Description: Natural gas and oxygen are received in our plant via pipeline and used as a feedstock.  The oxygen and natural gas are combined in gasifier in a process called partial oxidation (POX) reaction.  The partial oxidation process is a process where oxygen and natural gas are injected through a burner into a hot refractory lined gasifier.  The oxygen and natural gas are converted in the gasifier at 2500 F to syngas.  Syngas consists mainly of hydrogen and carbon monoxide.  Carbon dioxide and steam are also produced in the partial oxidation process.  Carbon dioxide is removed from the syngas by flowing through a scrubber.  The syngas is dried to remove moisture, and then separated into hydrogen and carbon monoxide through a cryogenic distillation process.  The carbon monoxide from the distillation process is compressed and delivered to customers via pipeline.  The hydrogen is sent through a pressure swing adsorber to remove residual carbon monoxide.  The pure hydrogen is then compressed and delivered to our customers via pipelines or filled into tube trailers and cylinders.  Back up hydrogen is provided by a 20,000-gallon liquid hydrogen storage tank and gaseous hydrogen storage tube banks.

The regulated substance handled at this facility is the flammable mixture.  The maximum amount of this substance is: 

?    81,000 pounds of flammable gas containing approximately 31% hydrogen and 10% methane
?    4000 pounds of chlorine stored in 2000 pound containers

3.  The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distance for each reported scenario:

Th

e ?worst-case scenario? (WCS) as defined by the EPA, associated with a catastrophic failure of the liquid hydrogen storage tank, releasing all 20,000 gallons (11,800 pounds) of hydrogen.  The total quantity of hydrogen is assumed to form a vapor cloud and ignite resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. (VCE).  Ten percent of the released quantity of hydrogen is assumed to participate in the explosion.  The maximum distance to the EPA defined endpoint (1 psi over pressure) for this WCS is 0.25 miles (1,337 feet).  Although we have active controls directed at preventing such releases and controlling the consequences, no credit for active mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this WCS.

The ?alternative case? (ACS) scenario for flammable substance at this facility is (1 psi) overpressure from a breakage in the E-102 heat exchanger inside the fired heater due to piping failure.  The entire inventory of the pipe and connections vessels of 7,100 pounds of a flammable substance is assumed to be released.  The maximum distance to the EPA defined overpressure end point is 0.13 miles.

The ?worst-case scenario? (WCS) as defined by the EPA, associated with a catastrophic failure of a chlorine storage container, releasing all 2,000 pounds of chlorine.  The maximum distance to the EPA defined endpoint (0.0087 mg/L) for this WCS reaches receptors offsite.  Although we have active controls directed at preventing such releases and controlling the consequences, no credit for active mitigation measures were taken into account in evaluating this WCS.

The ?alternative case? (ACS) scenario for a toxic substance at this facility is the failure of a 3/8 inch vapor line connected to a chlorine ton container as a result of mechanical damage or corrosion.  The entire inventory of the vessel and line is assumed to be released (2000 lbs).  The maximum distance to the EPA defined overpressure end point is 0.30 miles.


4.  The general accidental release prevention program and

specific prevention steps:

The facility developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Plan, and OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  The facility was designed and constructed to comply with applicable state and industry codes.

5.  Five-year accident history:

In the last five years there have been no accidents involving or accidental releases of flammable gas
or toxic gas that resulted in any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.


6.  The emergency response program:

The facility?s emergency response program is based upon OSHA?s HAZWOPER standard.  At this site, employees are trained to recognize emergencies and initiate emergency response from outside agencies.  They have been trained to OSHA?s First Responder Awareness Level.  The employees receive annual refresher training in their role in the emergency plan.  Emergency response activities have also been coordinated with the Channel Industries Mutual Aid for emergencies related to the Hydrogen process.  Periodic drills are conducted to review the effectiveness of our emergency procedures.  


7.  Planned changes to improve safety:

The facility resolves recommendations from PHAs and Incident Investigations, some of which may result in modifications to the plant design and operating procedures.
